Pocatello POTW Executive Summary

Pocatello's POTW is located west of the city at 10733 Rio Vista Road. The POTW treats  wastewater generated by the City of Pocatello, the City of Chubbuck, and some of the out lying Bannock County areas. The processes include primary and secondary treatment with disinfection using a final chlorination/dechlorination process prior to discharge to the Portneuf River. The City of Pocatello exceeds the threshold quantity for the chemicals chlorine and sulfur dioxide and must comply with the mandated EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP).

The two major elements in the RMP for Pocatello are the off site consequence analysis for chlorine and sulfur dioxide, both worst case and alternative release, and a prevention program. Pocatello's prevention plan includes information about safety, process hazards, operating procedures, training programs, maintenance programs, audits, and accident investigations. The offsite consequence analysis for both the worst case release scenario and alternative release scenario were completed using EPA's RMP*Comp program. Pocatello used EPA's TRI Program to determine facility latitude and longitude.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the past five years. The object of this plan is to continue this history and prevent any accidental releases and to respond effectively and timely in the unlikely event there is a release. Pocatello's RMP incident report form will be used in the unlikely event there is an accidental release.

Management System

The roles and responsibilities of the staff that oversee the risk management program elements will help to ensure effective communication about process changes between divisions; clarify the roles and responsibilities related to process safety issues; avoid confusion and allow team work; and ensure that the program elements are integrated into an ongoing approach to identifying hazards and managing risks.

Prevention

Program (Program 2)

Pocatello's prevention plan has integrated the seven basic elements - safety information, process hazards analysis, operating procedures, training programs, maintenance programs, compliance audits, and accident investigations into a risk management system. Safety information is used to perform a process hazard analysis and the results of the analysis are used to revise and update operating and maintenance procedures. Training programs ensure employees understand and manage risks are revised as needed and continued training is provided.

EPA requires Pocatello to review and update its hazard review at least once every five years. The review and all updates of the hazard review, as well as resolutions of any problems identified are documented.

Process Safety Information

Chlorine and sulfur dioxide have been used for many years for the chlorination/dechlorination processes at Pocatello's POTW. As references for chlorine and sulfur dioxide handling Pocatello uses "The Chlorine Manual" (The Chlorine Institute, 1986, 5th edition), "Chlorine and Its Properties" (Capitol Controls Company, Inc. 1990, Pub.No. 381-5), Sulfur Dioxide and Its Properties (Capitol Controls Company, Inc. 1989, Pub. No. 482-2), Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) BOC GASES, 1996, and Pocatello's "Operating Procedures for Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Cylinder Handling and Storage", 1999.

Operating Procedures

Operating procedures and instructions are important for training personnel and insuring safe operations of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems. The standard operating procedures (SOPs) for operating the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems and associated equipment are located in the operations office, maintenance office, and the operators lab which are accessible to all plant personnel. The SOPs cover everything from receiving the ton cylinders through valving the to various discharge points. SOPs include the start-up and shut down of all related handling equipment. SOPs

are updated as needed.

New employees are given general training in the hazards as part of their plant employee orientation. New operators are required to review and understand the SOPs and are given on the job training (OJT) on all chlorine and sulfur dioxide related tasks required as part of their operational duties. The maintenance employees also receive OJT before they are allowed to independently work on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems.

Maintenance

Written procedures for inspecting and testing are incorporated into a preventive maintenance (PM) program and have been in effect since the construction completion in 1992. The PM is conducted in accordance with the manufactures recommended procedures and sound engineering practices. The PM program is operated by a computer system that generates the needed information when a piece of equipment is in need of inspection or service.

Technical manuals for the process systems consist of three volumes which are current and located in the maintenance library.

Initial training on the process systems were conducted by construction contractor and equipment manufactures at completion of construction. Safety training requirements for maintenance personnel are the same as for operations personnel.

Incident Investigation

The intent of the incident investigation is to learn from past experiences and avoid future similar incidents. The incidents employees are expected to recognize and initiate the investigation process are the types of events that result or could have reasonably resulted in a major chlorine or sulfur dioxide release. That is what we may refer to as a "near miss" meaning that serious consequences did not occur, but could have.

Compliance Audit

The POTW is required under EPA regulations to self-audit its procedures and practices for compliance with the regulations at least every three years to verify their adequacy and implementation. Self audits are to be documented. A report of the findings of all a

udit are developed.

The POTW Superintendent or designee will determine and document a response to each deficiency identified in the compliance audit. Any deficiency noted in the audit will be corrected and documented as such.

The POTW will keep the two most recent compliance audit reports on file for internal purposes and EPA inspection.

Emergency Response Plan

Any time a chlorine or sulfur dioxide emergency is apparent or suspected, the operator in charge will initiate the procedure to assess the severity of the emergency. The procedure requires a minimum of two individuals to be present when an emergency is apparent or suspected. A minimum of "Level B" respiratory equipment will be required. The reason for a two party assessment is due to staffing levels.

Once the level of emergency has been assessed, the operator in charge will then make a determination as to what Action Response Procedure will be followed based on the information provided by the assessment. The operator in charge will immediately begin a record of the event.

Small leaks that are contained within the process building area may be repaired and alleviated through immediate action of trained POTW personnel. Large releases that may effect public and/or private receptors or risk personal injury to POTW personnel will be responded to by the Regional Hazmat Team (local fire department).
